dt: {bc}to cause to submit to or accept something unpleasant
{bc}to check (a financial account) against another for accuracy

pt: {sc}adapt{/sc} {sc}adjust{/sc} {sc}accommodate{/sc} {sc}conform{/sc} {sc}reconcile{/sc} mean to bring one thing into correspondence with another. {sc}adapt{/sc} implies a modification according to changing circumstances.
{sc}adjust{/sc} suggests bringing into a close and exact correspondence or harmony such as exists between parts of a mechanism.

pt.t: {it}adjusted{/it} the budget to allow for inflation

pt: {sc}accommodate{/sc} may suggest yielding or compromising to effect a correspondence.

pt.t: businesses {it}accommodating{/it} themselves to the new political reality

pt: {sc}conform{/sc} applies to bringing into accordance with a pattern, example, or principle.
{sc}reconcile{/sc} implies the demonstration of the underlying compatibility of things that seem to be incompatible.

pt.t: tried to {it}reconcile{/it} what he said with what I knew

quotes.t: By exposing the comic-pathetic quality of the human condition, it temporarily {qword}reconciles{/qword} us to that condition without creating in us complacence, lethargy, or any negative emotion.
It is a function of architecture to {qword}reconcile{/qword} technology with human cussedness, to make the mechanics of life endurable …
He thought they might {qword}reconcile{/qword} the Parisians to his daring design by reminding them of the familiar arches of their bridges.
She and Eddie had separated and {qword}reconciled{/qword} so many times the children had lost track of whose clothes were where.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French or Latin; Anglo-French {it}reconciler{/it}, from Latin {it}reconciliare{/it}, from {it}re-{/it} + {it}conciliare{/it} to conciliate
shortdef: to restore to friendship or harmony

dt.t: He eventually became {it}reconciled to{/it} his position in life.
